title: Lesson 11: Isotopes and Average Atomic Mass
content:
Lesson 11: Isotopes and Average Atomic Mass

Different Versions of the Same Element

If an atom's mass comes from whole protons and neutrons, why is the atomic mass of Chlorine on the periodic table 35.5? Can you have half a neutron?

This is one of the great puzzles in chemistry! You can't have half a proton or half a neutron. The mass number for any single atom is always a whole number. The reason for the decimal on the periodic table is that in nature, most elements exist as a mixture of atoms that are chemically identical but have different masses. These different "versions" of an element are called **isotopes**, and the number on the periodic table is their weighted average.

What Are Isotopes?

Isotopes are defined as atoms of the same element that have the same atomic number (same number of protons) but a different mass number (different number of neutrons).

Think of them as twins who are identical in their defining characteristic (their number of protons), but have different weights because they are carrying a different number of "bags" (neutrons).

Example: The Isotopes of Hydrogen

Hydrogen is the simplest example. All hydrogen atoms have 1 proton. But they can have 0, 1, or 2 neutrons.

Protium (¹H)

1 Proton, 0 Neutrons

Mass Number = 1

Deuterium (²H)

1 Proton, 1 Neutron

Mass Number = 2

Tritium (³H)

1 Proton, 2 Neutrons

Mass Number = 3

Since all isotopes of an element have the same number of protons, they also have the same number of electrons (in a neutral atom) and the same electronic configuration. This means isotopes of an element have identical chemical properties, but their physical properties (like mass) are different.

More Examples of Isotopes

Isotopes of Carbon

All Carbon atoms have 6 protons.

Carbon-12 (12C6)

6 Protons

6 Neutrons

Carbon-14 (14C6)

6 Protons

8 Neutrons

Isotopes of Chlorine

All Chlorine atoms have 17 protons.

Chlorine-35 (35Cl17)

17 Protons

18 Neutrons

Chlorine-37 (37Cl17)

17 Protons

20 Neutrons

Why is Atomic Mass a Decimal? The Weighted Average

As we saw, elements in nature are a mix of different isotopes. The atomic mass on the periodic table is a **weighted average** of the masses of these naturally occurring isotopes. This calculation takes into account how abundant (common) each isotope is.

Calculating Average Atomic Mass of Chlorine

Natural chlorine is a mix of two isotopes: Chlorine-35 and Chlorine-37 in a ratio of 3:1.

Step 1: Convert ratio to percentage.

There are 4 total parts (3+1). So,

  • Chlorine-35 is 3/4 = 75% of the sample.
  • Chlorine-37 is 1/4 = 25% of the sample.

Step 2: Calculate the weighted mass for each isotope.

Mass from Cl-35 = (Mass of isotope) x (% Abundance)
= 35 u x (75/100) = 26.25 u

Mass from Cl-37 = (Mass of isotope) x (% Abundance)
= 37 u x (25/100) = 9.25 u

Step 3: Add them together to find the average.

Average Mass = 26.25 u + 9.25 u = 35.5 u

This doesn't mean a single atom has a mass of 35.5 u. It means that if you scooped up a random sample of chlorine from nature, the **average mass** of the atoms in your scoop would be 35.5 u.

Summary: Isotopes vs. Atomic Mass

Isotopes

Atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.

They have the same atomic number (Z) but different mass numbers (A).

Average Atomic Mass

The weighted average mass of all the naturally occurring isotopes of an element.

This is the decimal number you see on the periodic table.

Lesson 11: Questions & Answers

1. Define the term "isotopes". What do isotopes of an element have in common, and what is different?

Isotopes are atoms of the same element with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons.

  • What's the same: They have the same number of protons (same atomic number, Z). Because of this, they have the same chemical properties.
  • What's different: They have a different number of neutrons. Because of this, they have different mass numbers (A) and different physical masses.

2. The element Carbon (C) has an atomic number of 6. Its two main isotopes are Carbon-12 and Carbon-14. How many protons and neutrons does each isotope have?

For Carbon-12:

Protons = Z = 6

Neutrons = A - Z = 12 - 6 = 6

For Carbon-14:

Protons = Z = 6

Neutrons = A - Z = 14 - 6 = 8

Answers:
- Carbon-12 has 6 protons and 6 neutrons.
- Carbon-14 has 6 protons and 8 neutrons.

3. For the symbol H, D and T, tabulate the three sub-atomic particles found in each of them.

First, let's identify what H, D, and T are:

  • H (Protium, ¹H): Mass Number = 1, Atomic Number = 1
  • D (Deuterium, ²H): Mass Number = 2, Atomic Number = 1
  • T (Tritium, ³H): Mass Number = 3, Atomic Number = 1
SymbolProtonsElectrons (neutral)Neutrons
H (Protium)110
D (Deuterium)111
T (Tritium)112

4. Why do all isotopes of a given element have identical chemical properties?

Because chemical properties are determined by the **number and arrangement of electrons**, especially the valence electrons.

  • All isotopes of an element have the same number of protons.
  • In a neutral state, this means they also have the same number of electrons.
  • Therefore, they have the same electronic configuration.

Since their electron structures are identical, they react chemically in the same way.

5. Why is the atomic mass listed on the periodic table usually a decimal number? For example, Chlorine is 35.5.

Because the atomic mass is a weighted average of the masses of an element's naturally occurring isotopes.

For Chlorine, it exists in nature as two main isotopes: Chlorine-35 (which is more abundant) and Chlorine-37. When you take a weighted average based on how common each one is, the average value comes out to 35.5. A single atom doesn't have a fractional mass, but the average of a large group does.

6. In nature, Bromine exists as two isotopes: Bromine-79 (49.7% abundance) and Bromine-81 (50.3% abundance). Calculate the average atomic mass of Bromine.

Step 1: Calculate the contribution of each isotope.

Mass from Br-79 = (Mass of isotope) × (% Abundance)

= 79 × (49.7 / 100) = 39.263 u

Mass from Br-81 = (Mass of isotope) × (% Abundance)

= 81 × (50.3 / 100) = 40.743 u

Step 2: Add the contributions together.

Average Mass = 39.263 + 40.743 = 80.006 u

Correct Answer: The average atomic mass of Bromine is approximately 80 u.

7. True or False: Isotopes of an element have the same physical properties.

False.

Isotopes have different numbers of neutrons, which gives them different masses. Physical properties that depend on mass, like density, boiling point, and melting point, will be slightly different for different isotopes. They have the same **chemical** properties.

8. Which part of the atom (protons, neutrons, or electrons) is different between isotopes of the same element?

The number of neutrons.

9. An element X has two isotopes, X-16 (90% abundance) and X-18 (10% abundance). What is its average atomic mass?

Step 1: Calculate each contribution.

Mass from X-16 = 16 × (90 / 100) = 14.4 u

Mass from X-18 = 18 × (10 / 100) = 1.8 u

Step 2: Add the contributions.

Average Mass = 14.4 + 1.8 = 16.2 u

Correct Answer: The average atomic mass of element X is 16.2 u.

10. All three isotopes of hydrogen (¹H, ²H, and ³H) have an atomic number of 1. Why?

Because the atomic number is determined by the number of protons. Since all three are isotopes of hydrogen, they all must contain exactly **1 proton**, which gives them an atomic number of 1.

11. A sample of chlorine has an average atomic mass of 35.5 u. Does this mean any single chlorine atom in the sample actually has a mass of 35.5 u? Explain.

No.

The mass of a single atom is determined by its mass number (protons + neutrons), which must be a whole number. Any single chlorine atom will have a mass of either 35 u or 37 u. The value 35.5 u is just the statistical average for a large group of atoms, not the mass of an individual atom.

12. An element has two main isotopes. One is very common (99%) and one is very rare (1%). Will the average atomic mass be closer to the mass of the common isotope or the rare one?

It will be much closer to the mass of the common (99%) isotope.

Since the calculation is a *weighted* average, the isotope with the higher abundance has a much bigger influence on the final average value.
exercises:
Lesson 11: Exercises

1. The Isotope Rule

Isotopes of an element have the same number of ___________ but a different number of ___________.

Protons, Neutrons

2. Finding Neutrons in an Isotope

One isotope of Uranium is 235U92. How many neutrons does this isotope have?

Neutrons = Mass Number (A) - Atomic Number (Z) = 235 - 92 = 143.

It has 143 neutrons.

3. Which is an Isotope?

An atom of element X has 8 protons and 8 neutrons. Which of the following is an isotope of X?

  1. An atom with 7 protons and 8 neutrons.
  2. An atom with 8 protons and 9 neutrons.
  3. An atom with 9 protons and 8 neutrons.

B. An atom with 8 protons and 9 neutrons.

Isotopes must have the same number of protons (which defines the element) but a different number of neutrons.

4. True or False?

All isotopes of carbon have the same mass number. (True / False)

False.

Isotopes of an element have different numbers of neutrons, which means they must have different mass numbers (e.g., Carbon-12 and Carbon-14).

5. Calculation Challenge

In a sample of Neon, 90% of the atoms have a mass of 20 u, and 10% of the atoms have a mass of 22 u. Calculate the average atomic mass of Neon.

Contribution from Neon-20 = 20 u × (90/100) = 18.0 u

Contribution from Neon-22 = 22 u × (10/100) = 2.2 u

Average Mass = 18.0 + 2.2 = 20.2 u.

The average atomic mass is 20.2 u.

6. Property Check

Would you expect Carbon-12 and Carbon-14 to react with oxygen in the same way or a different way? Explain.

In the same way.

Both are isotopes of carbon, meaning they have the same number of protons and electrons. Since chemical reactions depend on electron configuration, their chemical properties are identical.

7. Build the Isotope

Create the full standard notation (AXZ) for an isotope of Oxygen (Z=8) that has 10 neutrons.

Atomic number (Z) = 8. Mass number (A) = 8 protons + 10 neutrons = 18.

18 O 8

8. Spot the Twins

Which two of the following atoms are isotopes of each other?

AtomProtonsNeutrons
A1718
B1818
C1720

Atom A and Atom C are isotopes.

They both have 17 protons (making them both Chlorine), but they have different numbers of neutrons (18 and 20).

9. Visual Identification

Look at the two nuclei below. Are they isotopes? Why or why not?

Nucleus 1

Nucleus 2

No, they are not isotopes.

Nucleus 1 has 1 proton (red) and 2 neutrons (grey). Nucleus 2 has 1 proton and 1 neutron. While they have the same number of protons (and are therefore both Hydrogen), they are different isotopes, not the same one.

(Oops, the question asked if they *are isotopes*, and the answer should be YES, they are isotopes of each other! Correcting that.)

Corrected Answer: Yes, they are isotopes of each other.

They both have 1 proton, which makes them both Hydrogen. However, Nucleus 1 has 2 neutrons while Nucleus 2 has 1 neutron, so they are different isotopes of the same element.

10. True or False?

An element can have isotopes with different atomic numbers. (True / False)

False.

By definition, all atoms of an element have the same atomic number (same number of protons). Isotopes of that element must share that atomic number.

11. Missing Number

Carbon-13 has 6 protons. How many neutrons does it have?

7 neutrons

Neutrons = Mass Number - Protons = 13 - 6 = 7.

12. From Notation to Particles

How many protons and neutrons are in an atom of 37Cl17?

  • Protons: Equal to Z = 17.
  • Neutrons: A - Z = 37 - 17 = 20.

13. Decimal Detective

If a single atom cannot have a fractional mass, explain in one sentence why the atomic mass of many elements is a decimal.

The atomic mass is a weighted average of all the naturally occurring isotopes of that element, which results in a decimal value.

14. What if... ?

What if every element existed as only one type of atom (no isotopes)? What would you expect the atomic masses on the periodic table to look like?

All the atomic masses would be whole numbers.

Without different isotopes to average, the atomic mass would simply be equal to the mass number (an integer) of that one type of atom.

15. Final Check

Does changing the number of neutrons change an atom's valency?

No.

Valency is determined by the valence electrons. Since isotopes have the same number of protons, they also have the same number of electrons and the same electronic configuration. Therefore, they have the same valency.
intros:
Lesson 11: Isotopes and Average Atomic Mass

Exploring the different "flavors" of an element and how we calculate their average weight.

Intro 1: Atomic Twins

Can two people be identical twins but have different weights?

Yes, of course! Atoms can do the same thing. Sometimes, you find atoms of the same element that are identical in every chemical way, but they have different masses. This happens because they have the same number of protons (which makes them "twins" of the same element) but a different number of neutrons.

These "atomic twins" are called **isotopes**. For example, every Carbon atom has 6 protons, but some have 6 neutrons (making Carbon-12) while others have 8 neutrons (making Carbon-14). They are both still Carbon, but one is heavier. Since elements in nature are a mix of these isotopes, how do we find the "average" weight to put on the periodic table?

Isotopes: The twins of the atomic world.

Intro 2: The Extra Baggage

Imagine two identical cars, but one is carrying extra baggage. They are still the same car model, right?

The model of a car is defined by its engine. Two cars can be the same model but one might be carrying heavy luggage, making it heavier. Atoms are just like this! The "engine" that defines the element is its number of protons. A carbon atom is a carbon atom because it has a "6-proton engine."

However, some carbon atoms might be carrying "extra baggage" in their nucleus—extra neutrons. This doesn't change the car model (it's still Carbon), but it makes the atom heavier. These different versions of the same element, with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons, are called **isotopes**. This is why the mass on the periodic table is a decimal—it's the average weight of all the different "cars" found in nature.

Same element, just different amounts of luggage.

Intro 3: A Recipe for Carbon

The recipe for Carbon is always "6 protons." But what if you can add a little more or less of another ingredient?

Think of every element having a non-negotiable ingredient in its recipe: its number of protons. For Carbon, the recipe must always start with exactly 6 protons. If you change that, it's not Carbon anymore.

However, there's another ingredient—neutrons—where the amount can vary slightly. You can make Carbon with 6 neutrons, 7 neutrons, or even 8 neutrons. These different "recipes" produce different versions of Carbon that are all chemically the same but have different weights. These versions are called **isotopes**. The existence of multiple recipes is why we have to calculate an "average weight" for elements.

Same main ingredient, but with a few optional extras.

Intro 4: Why the Decimal?

Have you ever wondered why the atomic mass on the periodic table is a decimal, like 35.5 for Chlorine? Can you have half a proton?

Of course not! Protons and neutrons are whole particles. So why is the atomic mass not a whole number? The reason is that what we see on the periodic table is a **weighted average**. In nature, elements exist as a mixture of different versions, some heavier than others. These different versions are called **isotopes**.

For Chlorine, about 75% of its atoms are the lighter "Chlorine-35" and 25% are the heavier "Chlorine-37." When you calculate the average mass based on how common each one is, the result is 35.5. The decimal doesn't mean a single atom has a fractional weight; it means the average weight of a typical sample of atoms is a decimal.

Solving the mystery of the decimal on the periodic table.

Intro 5: Flavors of an Element

Ice cream comes in many flavors, but it's all still ice cream. Can an element have different "flavors"?

Yes, it can! Just like vanilla, chocolate, and strawberry are all flavors of ice cream, an element like Hydrogen can come in different "flavors" too. All these flavors have the same essential ingredient—1 proton—which is what makes them Hydrogen.

The difference between the flavors is the number of neutrons. The most common "flavor," Protium, has 0 neutrons. But there are also "heavy" flavors like Deuterium (1 neutron) and Tritium (2 neutrons). These different flavors of the same element are called **isotopes**. They are chemically identical but have different masses, and some have special properties that make them incredibly useful in medicine and science.

Exploring the different flavors of the atomic world.

Lesson 11: Summary

Isotopes and Average Atomic Mass

What are Isotopes?

Isotopes are atoms of the same element that have the same number of protons (same Atomic Number, Z) but a different number of neutrons, resulting in a different Mass Number (A).

What's the SAME?

  • Atomic Number (Z)
  • Number of Protons
  • Number of Electrons (in neutral atoms)
  • Chemical Properties

What's DIFFERENT?

  • Mass Number (A)
  • Number of Neutrons
  • Physical Properties (e.g., mass, density)

Example: The Isotopes of Hydrogen

Why are Atomic Masses Fractional? The Concept of Average Atomic Mass

The atomic mass listed on the periodic table is a weighted average of the masses of all naturally occurring isotopes of an element, based on their abundance (how common they are in nature).

Example: Calculation for Chlorine (Cl)

Chlorine exists as two main isotopes in nature:

  • - ³⁵Cl has a mass of 35u and an abundance of 75%.
  • - ³⁷Cl has a mass of 37u and an abundance of 25%.
Average Mass = (35 u × 75/100) + (37 u × 25/100)
Average Mass = (26.25 u) + (9.25 u)
Average Mass = 35.5 u

Conclusion: This doesn't mean a single chlorine atom weighs 35.5u. It means that in any natural sample of chlorine, the average mass of an atom will be 35.5u.
